comments.comment: Japan treating YouTubers like terrorists is so hilarious and entirely valid.

As someone who has been living in Japan for almost 20 years, I find it very frustrating that people like that are coming here and giving the impression that many foreigners are like that. Sad and frustrating.

I am Japanese. Japanese people are friendly towards foreigners who respect Japanese culture. I love Pewdie. Many foreigners seem to misunderstand this, but we don't hate foreigners. We just hate rude foreigners who try to destroy Japanese culture.
As an international student in Japan it hurts my heart when my fellow other international students  can't follow the rules(J-walk, throw cigarettes on the ground, leave other trash on the ground)
Thankfully Felix isn't a YouTuber like the PewDiePie guy.
Finally someone said something, years ago everyone was like "i wanna go to japan to have fun" now its "i wanna go to japan for clout"
I appreciate that you blurred them. They don't deserve any attention at all.

いつも、楽しくみてます。
私は普段、外国人観光客を相手に仕事してます。
はっきり注意してもムスッとされたり、笑ってヘラヘラされる事結構多いです。
京都に知り合いがいますが、京都も酷いみたいです。
本来、観光地ではない祇園に人が集中してたり、舞子さんへの過激な追い回しからの容赦ない写真撮影。
私有地を勝手に撮影して、勝手に侵入する。
京都の友人ももう限界だと言っておりました

動画にして下さり、ありがとうございます。
みんな気持ちよく日本を観光地出来ますように。

We Japanese welcome tourists who respect culture and manners.
Every country has its culture, its rules and manners.
Damn im looking good in this video!

There's 2 Types of Foreign YouTubers going to japan.

1. A clout chaser that ruins everything
2. You're gonna be Chris Abroad 2.0
Honestly, I am glad Japan takes this YouTuber epidemic. Pewds covered the true news of this. I appreciate this
Japan really need to take serious action against these disrespectful people.
I went to Japan two weeks ago, and some of the tourists were being respectful, some didn't follow basic etiquette. I respect the police trying to get rid of these harassers.
日本の時事を世界に発信してくれるのは本当に助かる
As another european the biggest appeal of going to Japan would be to be around a culture that is so fundamentally polite. Why the fuck would rude people even want to go there?
10:47 this editor put in so much work this entire video to make ken feel actually there. Great job man doesn't go unnoticed

In Japan, it is not considered a good idea to take videos of ordinary people or passers-by with a camera, so YouTubers who do so are not looked at very well.
It is natural that it would be considered rude not to adapt to the culture and manners of the country.

I've been to Japan recently for the first time in my life. An amazing country, super polite people. And I truly despise the disrespectful behaviours of some/many tourists. Those shown in the video are absolutely disgusting. When people will finally understand that if you travel to some other country, you are a guest, you should respect the local culture and customs. I fully agree with the restrictions imposed by Japanese authorities, I even think they should be more strict with the police and fines. Seriously, if you want to see Mt Fuji, a temple, anything else, just be grateful for this opportunity and do NOT act as if you were ENTITLED to do so! Exactly this attitude pisses me off so much. Japanese can restrict access to areas, they can build fences, they can give fines and (hopefully) put to jail, because it it their home, their country and they set the rules - not some stupid, obnoxious tourists! These should apply to any other place in the world, maybe then some people will finally learn, that their behaviour is wrong and they aren't entitled to anything...

Its sad to see people disrespect Japan and act like idiots because its really one of the most unique places out there. Its safe and clean and mostly everyone is polite. Obviously its got its own problems that need solving but i hope the good aspects of it never change because of people like this.
The amount of effort to edit in Ken’s reaction using different photos is insane and so honorable.

Not even just youtubers, just this morning I saw a video of a clearly american middle aged Karen hounding a Japanese woman in traditional clothing in Kyoto trying to take a picture. The japanese woman was clearly trying to run away and this Karen kept running in front of her to take a picture. Some of the tourist treat Japan like Disneyland.

日本は貴方の様な外国の方を歓迎しています。日本を壊しに来るテロリストは民族に関わらずお断りです。
貴方を応援しています。
I just went to Japan and was absolutely floored by the amount of tourists NOT fellowing proper etiquette or simple rules of Japanese culture. It's a shame.
I hate these disrespectful youtubers going to another country to ruin it. I always make sure to report it for inappropriate content

felixs laugh at 3:40 was so nice to see, i love seeing people laugh that hard. felix and kens friendship is amazing

As an expat living in Japan, this behave is extremely upsetting to me. YouTubers and tourists come here and behave badly then leave, but those of us that live here have to deal with the consequences of their actions.
Felix using Zoom instead of discord is akin to when KSI found out he was still using bandicam haha.

Nothing better than seeing this duo back at it

100% disrespectful lmao. Some people are saying that Japan is over reacting but if the same shit happened in any other country they'd get a much worse ending than just thrown into a cell for a day. Imagine doing this shit in Brazil or most countries in South America or even worse in China, you bet your sweet ass someone is dying.

You've gotta mention Speed as well. He's been going around and harassing people in Japan as well.
Honestly all those other YouTubers even if they are not harassing or doing anything technically illegal, they are still a nuisance and a bother to people in public.

Because, recently, many Japanese has been feeling  a lot of frustration about recent stupid behavior of some foreign YouTuber, I believe this kind support from non-Japanese person is very helpful to keep good relationships between Japanese and residents who live in Japan.

I live in Tokyo, and every Sunday I have to clean up around my neighborhood because many tourists come to drink outside every weekend. Right now, I’m in the hospital and will be here for a while, but I’m worried about my area—there’s definitely going to be a lot of trash. I want to ask something of people who come to visit our country: please respect our town and its people. It’s okay if you can’t speak Japanese; there’s always someone who can help you

This kind of thing happens here in Portugal as well, disrespectful tourists usually crowd places and don't respect the local traditions and culture, throwing trash, jaywalking, et cetera. It's depressing to see your own city turn into a hellhole in real time.

普段の動画を見たらわかるけど、IKEA行ったりサイゼリア行ったりロッククライミングしたり…家族で穏やかに暮らしてる人だよ。

日本人ですが、殆どの外国人旅行者は日本が好きで来てくれることを知っています。
気負わずに気軽に来てください。いつでもウェルカムです。
殆どの方は分かっていると思いますが、ジョニーソマリやローガンポールのような迷惑なことをする人には日本人は徹底して嫌います。
これはどの国でも同じですよね。
旅行の際は最低限で良いのでその国のルールや文化を知ってから行くべきです。
It has been an honor boys. We did it.

As an American tourist and small YouTuber currently in Japan, I try to be as respectful and follow the rules as best as I can and not try to be obnoxious cause I dont want to be seen as one of “those dumb American tourists”. And whenever I see tourists do dumb things, I’m like “really?”. To prove my case, the other day I was at the Arashiyama Bamboo Forest, and theres a level crossing on a main railway line. There a signs LITERALLY saying, “DO NOT WALK ON TRACKS TO TAKE PICTURES”. And what did I see people doing? Exactly that! Like Okay, just stand there when the railroad crossing activates. My point is, not everyone is bad, but these kinds of people give tourists a bad rep.

東京・銀座のUNIQLO前の道で外国人観光客が地べたに座るの本当にやめてほしいんだよね
日本文化を理解しようとして来てくれる外国人観光客は大歓迎です🫶

11:28 That "Ginger Terror" case does look tame, but there was another incident that's probably the one Felix was thinking of initially, where some teenager went to Sushiro (a huge conveyor belt sushi chain) and filmed himself licking the spouts of soy sauce bottles, then licking pieces of sushi on the conveyor belt and putting them back (likely later eaten by unsuspecting customers), etc. The video went viral and caused a hygiene panic which affected Sushiro's revenue and market cap drastically.
Ken being uncle Max is so accurate lol

This is our culture and way of thinking. I’m Japanese. We’re so glad a lot of foreign tourists visit Japan. I really appreciate that. However, some people are lack of respect to our culture and rules. We literally hate these people. If you guys don’t wanna follow the rules, you should not visit to and live in Japan. It's very annoying. They can lose the trust of foreigners who like Japan with respect.

日本人は迷惑行為をする外国人に困ってるだけですからね。これも人種等は関係ありません。日本の法律やルール、文化、歴史等、守る気がない人は来ないで下さい。自分の国で同じ事をされたら気分を害するはずです。

i'm not Japanese and never been there (i wish i could one day) but it's seriously annoying seeing people going there and doing disrespectful stuffs fully knowing Japanese culture just to mock them. hell even in my country it's annoying to have foreigners/tourist coming and do cringe shit
本当にありがとう。いつまでも日本に居てください。

Many Japanese people, including myself, appreciate your videos. I always feel happy when I watch videos of your family's daily life. The more I got to know you, the more I became a fan of your family. Thank you very much for coming to Japan.

This is so frustrating. Terrible tourists and YouTubers are ruining my country. I love when there are tourists and YouTubers who respect my culture and follow Japan’s societal rules, but it seems like a lot of tourists aren’t doing that and are taking advantage of the Japanese people. It’s absolutely disgusting. On top of that, there are certain people on the internet promoting bad behavior or encouraging followers to prey on Japanese women specifically because they’re thought to be “submissive”. That’s why I don’t tell people I’m Japanese anymore because when I do, they start asking me very personal questions and the way they look at me completely changes. It’s very frustrating and I hope tourists and YouTubers make an effort to learn more about a country before they visit, and I hope any bad behavior is corrected or punished.

It makes me sad that people are so bloody disrespectful in other countries. When I was in Japan I was so careful to be as small and unobtrusive as possible. I was there to enjoy the place and the culture, not to try to influence it. Leave as you find, as they say. I quickly adapted to the cross-walks being flippin' everywhere and just learned to do what others did. Not complicated!
Actually for all you to know. Feidias (the guy who hide in the train bathroom) is now elected in the europe council in Bruxelles
ピューディーパイ氏のことをジョニーソマリは1億人の影響力があるなら何かしろと言っていたが、このような動画をあげるだけで十分な注意喚起の動画になるためありがたいと思っている。

In Kyoto, incidents like placing cigarettes inside a maiko's kimono and grabbing their hair have led to changes in the culture of geisha and maiko freely walking around town. Additionally, drones have been flown into military facilities and posted on social media, resulting in alarming news. This is more of an issue with people not following the rules than just YouTubers.

It is true that there is a lack of responsiveness and many outdated rules in Japan, and we hope that both sides can change to achieve mutual satisfaction.
That little artbreak with his sketchpad is so darn cute
the craziest thing is this youtuber from cyprus became a Member of the European Parliament.
I love how Ken isn’t really there so all the video is random screenshots and animation

lmao the best part that you pointed out was that he LITERALLY NEEDS  to have a ticket or a JR rail pass to get to the point of being in the Shinkansen area to get on that train, unless he hopped over, in which case he would have been caught before he even got on the train

As a student currently visiting Japan, I can say this topic of this video is entirely true. Japan is being absolutely ruined by foreign non-resident YouTubers. Clickbaiters, annoying little turds running around causing a disturbance and not respecting etiquette, and even those who think they're helping but as a result create problems for the very groups they are trying to help all ruin the travel experience. 

For example, I'm doing a lot of retro game hunting here and it was clear at some point the prices were very good, and  there were a lot of smaller shops that are real hidden gems which offer superb prices as well as a variety of harder to find items. However, as I was making my way through various shops, I found a myriad of youtubers who track each shop's stock and upload it as videos. Some of them find some deals, but the second they find a deal and choose not to purchase said deal, someone goes to scoop everything they found up. Now, prices are sky high at even more remote and smaller shops. Even the local shops in my neighborhood have people. I respect what they do for their communities, but they absolutely ruin any fun of approaching a shop and being surprised by a cool inventory. 

Don't get me wrong, the prices in many cases will adjust due to the weak yen needing to change, so some of it makes sense, but just that alone doesn't add up for why some prices are so high at smaller shops. This means game the spotting they do clearly pushes demand up for some items as tourists scoop them up and remove them from a reselling pool at an accelerated rate due to people being more easily informed. As a result, prices inflate more quickly and make stuff less accessible.

Overall, I have nothing against the people from these game hunting channels. Each person I met was very nice, and had a passion for what they were doing. I just wish it wouldn't have the effect it does on the market, and I also wish they'd do more content about the games  themselves instead of ruining cool spots with good prices. With that, they're much better than the people running through tourist spots with camera rigs shoving it in everyone's faces.

This is so crazy that you filmed this film right now. A few days ago, in Poland is drama, becase polish youtuber did a couple stupid challenges, and she didn't respect japaneise culture at all. What a coinsidence.

In Japan, earthquakes and other disasters occur, and afterwards, there are cases where foreign photographers come to deserted towns for shooting or people come to steal items from the disaster-stricken areas, or even commit rape.
We stand with Japan
